titleStmt.title: Intermittent hypoxia in utero damages postnatal growth and cardiovascular function in rats

analytic.title: Intermittent hypoxia in utero damages postnatal growth and cardiovascular function in rats

biblStruct.note: Submitted 5 December 2016; accepted in final form 4 December 2017

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is common in pregnancy and may compromise fetal and even postnatal development.
We developed an animal model to determine if maternal OSA could have lasting effects in offspring.
Pregnant Sprague-Dawley rats were exposed to reduced ambient O2 from 21 to 4 -5%, approximately once per minute [chronic intermittent hypoxia (CIH)] for 8 h/day during gestation days 3-19.
Similarly handled animals exposed to ambient air served as controls (HC).
Offspring were studied for body growth and cardiovascular function for 8 postnatal weeks.
Compared with HC, prenatal CIH led to growth restriction, indicated by smaller body weight and tibial length, and higher arterial blood pressure in both male and female offspring.

Compared with same-sex HC, CIH males showed abdominal obesity (greater ratio of abdominal fat weight to body weight or tibial length), left ventricular (LV) hypertrophy (greater heart weight-to-tibial length ratio and LV posterior wall diastolic thickness), elevated LV contractility (increases in LV ejection fraction, end-systolic pressure-volume relations, and preload recruitable stroke work), elevated LV and arterial stiffness (increased end-diastolic pressure-volume relationship and arterial elasticity), and LV oxidative stress (greater lipid peroxide content).
Compared with female CIH offspring, male CIH offspring had more profound changes in blood pressure (BP), cardiac function, myocardial lipid peroxidase (LPO) content, and abdominal adiposity.

Rodent prenatal CIH exposure, mimicking human maternal OSA, exerts detrimental morphological and cardiovascular effects on developing offspring; the model may provide useful insights of OSA effects in humans.
NEW & NOTEWORTHY Obstructive sleep apnea is common in human pregnancy.

Following maternal exposure to chronic intermittent hypoxia, a hallmark of sleep apnea, both sexes of rat offspring showed growth retardation, with males being more vulnerable to hypertension and dysfunctional left ventricular changes.
This model is useful to study detrimental effects of maternal obstructive sleep apnea on developing offspring in humans.
Sleep-disordered breathing, including obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), is common in pregnant women.
Habitual snoring occurs in 10 -27% of pregnant women during the third trimester (47), and ~5% of pregnant women exhibit OSA (2).
OSA is a well-known risk factor for cardiometabolic mortality and morbidity in the general population (12,24,57).

While embryogenesis depends on maternal metabolic support (33), clinical studies indicate that OSA impairs maternal and fetal health and leads to gestational hypertension, diabetes, preeclampsia, premature delivery, fetal growth restriction, fetal brain injury, and even stillbirth (27,32,46).

Investigation into the mechanisms leading to these adverse effects is hampered by lack of a well-characterized animal model that could be used to determine effects of maternal OSA and postnatal effects on offspring.
We developed an animal model of OSA and evaluated essential morphologic and cardiovascular consequences to prenatal exposure to a principal aspect of human OSA, chronic intermittent hypoxia (CIH).
CIH, defined as cyclical decreases followed by rapid restoration of blood oxygen saturation associated with apnea, is a major feature of OSA.
In rodents, CIH exposure leads to cardiovascular injury, including hypertension, left ventricular (LV) hypertrophy, LV dysfunction, myocardial apoptosis, and oxidative stress (8,9,13,25,42).
Other noncardiac metabolic disturbance, such as hyperlipidemia, glucose intolerance, and brain injury have also been demonstrated (15).
Furthermore, even relatively brief postnatal CIH exposure in rats leads to adverse effects, sustained well after the exposure has ended.
A 1-h period of hypoxia exposure in newborn rats led to a combination of increased glucose and decreased insulin levels in blood, and fracture-prone bones were observed at 3 wk later (34,44).
Similarly, hypoxia exposure in neonates induced hypertension (11) and sympathetic nerve hyperactivity that was sustained until adulthood (11,58).
Exogenous substances such as cigarette smoke, caffeine, and air pollution profoundly impair fetal growth and morphogenesis (33), as well as cardiac function, even through adulthood (17).

Similarly, several forms of in utero hypoxia lead to postnatal growth restriction and brain injury, whether produced by cigarette smoke (24,51), brief and low-grade intermittent hypoxia (66), or other forms of transient hypoxia (23,54).

Our principal aim was to determine the consequences of prenatal CIH exposure on offspring body morphology and cardiovascular physiology and thus provide an animal model relevant to understanding the effects of maternal CIH exposure on the offspring developing fetus during the postnatal period.

A well-characterized model relevant to the effects of maternal OSA on fetal and postnatal development would be useful to investigate the mechanisms by which maternal OSA could lead to fetal and postnatal abnormalities.
We hypothesized that CIH exposure, which models certain aspects of OSA, would lead to growth retardation and show detrimental effects on postnatal cardiovascular function.
Animals.

All protocols were approved by the Animal Care and Use Committee of the University of Maryland School of Medicine and conformed to the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals (Institute for Laboratory Animal Research, National Academy of Sciences, 8th ed., 2011).
In 15 female Sprague-Dawley rats, pregnancy was confirmed by vaginal plugs by the supplier (Charles River Laboratories, Wilmington, MA).
Once pregnancy was confirmed, the dams were shipped the following day (gestation day 2) to the animal housing facility of the University of Maryland School of Medicine.
Dams were housed in pairs with free access to tap water and standard rodent chow in standard rat cages with room temperature of 23°C and light-dark cycle of 12 h.
After 24 h of acclimatization upon arrival, the rats were then exposed daily to either CIH (n ϭ 6) or similarly handled but exposed only to room air (n ϭ 9) from gestation days 3-19 (see below).
In preparation for birth, on gestation day 20, dams were housed individually and received no hypoxic exposure.
All offspring were weaned from the mothers on the postnatal day 21 and housed in pairs with free access to food and water.
Mothers were euthanized after the weaning.

Offspring body weight were measured weekly during weeks 4 -8, blood glucose concentration was measured on weeks 4 and 8, tail arterial blood pressure was measured at week 8, and echocardiography and cardiac pressure-volume loop analysis were performed at week 8.
CIH exposure.

As reported previously (8), animals were placed in the chambers of an environment system (HypOxyc system, Kent Scientific, Torrington, CT) for room air or hypoxia exposure, with free mobility and access to water and food.
Ambient oxygen concentration in the chambers was individually manipulated by alternative cycling of nitrogen gas and room air (21% oxygen).
Each phase of hypoxia alternating with normoxia lasted 60 s, with a nadir oxygen concentration of 4 -5% during hypoxia, and a maximum oxygen concentration of 21%.
The hypoxia-normoxia cycle was repeated for 8 h/day light-on exposure during gestation days 3-19.
Between exposures, the dams were returned to their normal housing cages.
Similarly, handled controls (HC) were placed in identical chambers on the same bench top, except a continuous flow of room air (21% oxygen) was maintained during the exposure hours.
Implanting arterial access port and arterial blood gases analysis.
In a separate group of pregnant dams, we measured changes in arterial blood gas compositions during intermittent hypoxia.

To enable repeated collection of arterial blood in freely moving animals, a vascular access port (ROP; Access Technologies, Skokie, IL) was implanted using sterile surgery and anesthesia with 2-3% of isoflurane inhalation in six additional rats.
The right common carotid artery was isolated through an anterior neck incision.
One of the port's catheters (2 French) was filled with heparinized saline, inserted into the artery near the carotid bifurcation and advanced into the ascending aorta.
The other end of the port was introduced into a subcutaneous pocket in the mid-scapular area and secured by suturing (5-0 nylon).
Subcutaneous Carprofen (4 -5 mg/kg, once a day) was administered postoperatively.
After recovery from surgery (7 days), the rats were mated for pregnancy and received the aforementioned CIH exposure.

The port was accessed with a right angle Huber needle (Access Technologies) puncturing through skin and the port septum and flushed with 50 -100 l of heparinized saline, once a day or following every sampling.
Arterial blood was sampled at exposure days 1, 3, and 15 (i.e., embryonic days 3, 6, and 19, respectively), using a chilled and heparinized syringe attached to a catheter and a needle.
On the sampling day, one blood sample was collected from HC dams, i.e., baseline.
Three blood samples were collected from CIH dams, including baseline (before start of exposure), and then following 2-h exposure, at times corresponding to the hypoxia and the reoxyenation phases.

From each 100 l, the first 50 l were discarded and arterial blood gas tensions (PO 2, PCO2, and pH) were measured from the remainder using an arterial blood gas analyzer (ABL90 FLEX; Radiometer, Brea, CA).
Arterial blood pressure.
In the offspring, systolic blood pressure (SBP) and heart rate (HR) were measured while the animals were conscious, using a MC4000 tail-cuff system (Hatteras Instruments, Cary, NC).
Animals were restrained using a mouse holder integrated with a heating pad set to 95°F.
To minimize measurement variation, animals were acclimatized to the system for 2 consecutive days in the holder and BP readings were taken the third day.
A total of 5-10 readings of BP and HR were taken and were used for analysis.
The variation was Ͻ15%.
BP and HR were also measured during pressurevolume loop analysis when animals were under general anesthesia (see below).
Echocardiography.
Animals were anesthetized by inhalation of 1.2-1.5% isoflurane in pure oxygen, with core temperature maintained at 37.5°C using a thermoregulated platform (THM 150; Indus Instruments, Houston, TX).

Transthoracic M-mode images of the LV in the parasternal short-axis view were obtained at the level of the papillary muscles using a high-resolution ultrasound biomicroscope (Vevo 2100, VisualSonics, Toronto, Canada) equipped with a 30-MHz scan head.
Data were calculated according to generally accepted formulas as previously described (8,9) and validated in rats (56).
LV pressure-volume loop analysis.
Pressure-volume loop analysis is a well-established technique for in vivo measurements of heart performance and is less affected by vascular loading conditions in rats (45).
We modified the methodology described by Patcher et al. (45).

Animals anesthetized using 2-2.5% isoflurane inhalation were orally intubated and ventilated with a rodent ventilator (Model 683; Harvard Instruments, Holliston, MA), at a tidal volume of 12-15 ml/kg body wt with 50 -80 strokes/min.

Through a front neck incision, a P10 silicone tube was placed into the left jugular vein for administration of 0.9% sodium chloride (0.1 ml•g body wt Ϫ1 •h Ϫ1 ), and a 1.9-F conductance catheter (Transonic Scisence, London, ON, Canada) into the LV through the right carotid artery.

Midline laparotomy was performed, and the inferior vena cava (IVC) was visualized at the level of the origin of the right renal vein after the abdominal tissues were gently retracted using 37°C wet (0.9% sodium chloride) gauze.
A 4 -0 silk suture was placed around the IVC and exteriorized through the abdominal wound, which was covered with the warm wet gauze.

Once the surgeries were completed, isofluorane concentration was reduced to 1.5%, and following a 15-min stabilization, the LV pressure and volume data were simultaneously recorded using the ADVantage PV System (ADV500; Transonic-Scisense).
During the recording, temporary IVC occlusion was performed by pulling the IVC suture for 8 -10 s, with a simultaneous shut-off of the ventilator.
The IVC occlusion was repeated three times at intervals of at least 5 min apart.
Following the LV study, the catheter was repositioned for recordings of aortic BP.
The data were analyzed offline using LabChart Pro (Version 8.1.5;

ADInstruments, Sydney, Australia), with a 10-min data averaged for static parameters, e.g., LV diastolic or systolic pressure (LVPd or LVPs), and 5-to 8-s data for the occluded parameters, e.g., slopes of LV end-systolic or end-diastolic pressurevolume relationships (ESPVR and EDPVR, respectively).
ESPVR was defined as a linear relationship, and EDPVR was defined as an exponential relationship, which provide an index of LV myocardial contractility or stiffness, respectively.
The isovolumic relaxation constant (tau), a preload-independent measure of isovolumic relaxation, was calculated using the Glantz method.
All other indexes were defined according to generally accepted formulas (45).
Tissue collection and analysis.
Tissue collection was carried out when the offspring were 8 wk old.
Following euthanasia (using 5% isoflurane inhalation following by thoracotomy), hearts and abdominal white fat pads were excised and weighed.
The right tibia was dissected and removed for measurement of the tibial length.
Heart and fat pads were flushed with PBS solution (pH 7.4) and frozen with liquid nitrogen.

Heart and fat pad tissues were homogenized at 4°C with PBS and analyzed with a colorimetric assay using a commercially available kit (Biotech LPO-586; Oxis International, Portland, OR) for measurements of lipid peroxidation (LPO) ( 8), an index of oxidant stress.

Cytosolic (Cu/Zn) superoxide dismutase (SOD), an index of antioxidant capacity, was measured using a commercially available kit (Bioxytech Oxisresearch SOD-525; Oxis International) after extraction with ethanol-chloroform to inactivate mitochondrial and extracellular SOD (8).
Protein concentration was determined using a protein assay kit (Bio-Rad Laboratories, Hercules, CA) (8), which was used for normalization of tissue LPO content and SOD activity.
Data analysis.
Data were compiled and expressed as means Ϯ SE.

Three-factor or two-factor ANOVA with post hoc analysis (Newman-Keuls) was used, respectively, with factors being sex, exposure type, and animal age for body weight; or exposure type, day, and phase or type for arterial blood gases or sex and exposure type for other indexes.
The 2 -test was used to test for differences in rate of failing to generate offspring between CIH and HC controls.
Student's t-test for unpaired variates was used to test differences in litter size between the two groups.
The null hypothesis was rejected at the 5% level.
Fifteen dams were exposed to either room air (controls, 9 dams) or CIH (6 dams).
There were four controls and two CIH-exposed dams who failed to yield any offspring.
However, the failure rate to generate offspring did not significantly differ between the two groups (44.4 vs. 33.3%,
P Ͼ 0.05, 2 -test).
There was a total of 110 offspring produced by 5 HC and 4 CIH dams.
These offspring consisted of 21 males and 20 females from the CIH dams and 35 males and 34 females from the HC dams that were included in the study.

There were no significant differences between CIH and HC groups in litter size or sex distribution (HC male: 5.8 Ϯ 1.3 per litter; HC female: 5.7 Ϯ 2.3; CIH male: 5.3 Ϯ 2.2; CIH female: 5.0 Ϯ 1.8; P Ͼ 0.05, two-way ANOVA).
Arterial blood gases.
A separate set of dams (n ϭ 6) was studied for arterial blood gas changes during CIH and eutha-nized following the final sampling of arterial blood at embryonic day 19.

As summarized in Table 1, there were no significant differences in any blood gas measures among the three baselines over the course of the pregnancy for either HC or CIH group or between HC and CIH baselines.

On the 3 days tested, arterial PO 2 was significantly lower than baseline during both the hypoxia and reoxygenation phase, compared with their preexposure baseline (P Ͻ 0.01) with significantly greater decreases during the hypoxia phase compared with the reoxygenation phase (P Ͻ 0.05).

Arterial PCO 2 decreased significantly during the hypoxia phase at all the timing points compared with their baseline (P Ͻ 0.01 or 0.05); however, the PCO 2 reduction in the reoxygenation phase significantly differed from the hypoxia phase only at the first day of the exposure (P Ͻ 0.01).
Arterial pH increased from the baseline in the hypoxia phase only on day 1 (P Ͻ 0.05).
Prenatal CIH led to growth restriction and abdominal obesity.

Three-way ANOVA revealed significant differences in body weight of offspring (Fig. 1) for all the three factors of exposure (CIH vs. HC, P Ͻ 0.05), sex (male vs. female, P Ͻ 0.01), and age (4 -8 wk, P Ͻ 0.01).

As Fig. 1 shows, as compared between CIH and HC in the same sex at the same time points, body weight was significantly lower (P Ͻ 0.05 or P Ͻ 0.01) at weeks 4, 7, and 8 in CIH males and at weeks 4, 6, 7, and 8 for CIH females.
Moreover, compared with females with the same treatment at the same time point, males had a significant greater body weight from weeks 5-8 (P Ͻ 0.01).

Finally, compared over time (weeks 4-8) within the same sex and same treatment, body weight at the later week of all the four groups was significantly greater than that at the previous week, i.e., week 5 was greater than week 4, and so on (P Ͻ 0.01 for all).
Tibial length, body weight, and fat weight were measured at week 8.
As seen in Fig. 2, tibial length was shorter in the CIH animals than the HC for either males or females (P Ͻ 0.01 for both).
The body weight-to-tibial length ratio was less in CIH females when compared with female controls (P Ͻ 0.05), but the differences between male CIH and HC were not significant.

There were no significant differences in the weight of abdominal white fat pads in either the CIH male or female offspring compared with their HC (male, CIH vs. HC: 4.4 Ϯ 0.3 vs. 3.9 Ϯ 0.2 g, P Ͼ 0.05; female: 4.01 Ϯ 0.2 vs. 4.1 Ϯ 0.2 g, P Ͼ 0.05).

Compared with their HC, CIH males showed a significantly greater ratio of the fat weight to either body weight or to tibial length (Fig. 2, C and D, P Ͻ 0.05 for both), but the differences were not significant in the female offspring.

Within the HC and the CIH groups, males had significantly greater tibial length (Fig. 2A, P Ͻ 0.01 for both) and ratio of body weight to tibial length (Fig. 2B, P Ͻ 0.01 for both), but a smaller ratio of fat weight to body weight (Fig. 2C, P Ͻ 0.01 for both).
Prenatal CIH increases arterial blood pressure and heart weight.

Figure 3 shows blood pressure and heart weight ratio to body weight or tibial length at week 8. Compared with samesex HC, conscious SBP (Fig. 3A) was increased significantly in both sexes in CIH-treated animals.

The SBPs, compared with the same-sex controls (HC), were greater in male CIH animals than in the female CIH animals, when expressed as absolute values or as percent differences (33% increase in males, 9% increase in females; P Ͻ 0.01 for both).

Mean, systolic, and diastolic arterial blood pressure (MAP, SBP, and DBP, Fig. 3, B-D), as measured under anesthesia, were significantly elevated in CIH males compared with HC males (P Ͻ 0.05 or 0.01), but the differences in arterial blood pressure between CIH and HC in the females were not significant.

Comparing male and female CIH groups, male rats had a greater conscious SBP and sedated SBP and MAP (Fig. 3, A-C, P Ͻ 0.05, respectively), although the difference in DBP was not significant (Fig. 3D).
There were no significant differences between male and female HC in any indexes of blood pressure.

There were no significant differences in heart weight at week 8 between CIH and the same-sex HC; however, the ratio of heart weight to either body weight or to tibial length (Fig. 3, E and F) was greater in CIH males (P Ͻ 0.01 and P Ͻ 0.05, respectively).
For the female animals, there were no significant differences in heart weight relative to body weight or tibial length between CIH and HC.
Compared with females with the same treatment, male CIH or male HC had a greater ratio of heart weight to tibial length (Fig. 3F, P Ͻ 0.01 for both).
Echocardiography.

Results of transthoracic echocardiography of the left ventricle are summarized in Fig. 4. Compared with male HC, CIH male offspring showed no significant changes in LV systolic or diastolic dimension (LVDs and LVDd; Fig. 4, A and B).

However, there were significant increases in diastolic left ventricular posterior wall thickness (LVPWd, Fig. 4C) and LV mass index (LVMI, normalized ratio of LV mass to body weight, Fig. 4D), suggesting LV hypertrophy in male CIH.

Similarly, there were significant increases in LV ejection fraction (LVEF; Fig. 4E) and LV fractional shortening (LVFS; Fig. 4F) in CIH males compared with HC males, presumably the consequence of an elevated myocardial contractility.
Unlike the aforementioned changes in CIH male offspring, CIH females showed no changes in LVPWd, LVEF, and LVFS compared with female HC (Fig. 4, C, E, and F, respectively).
Moreover, compared with female HC, CIH females had significantly smaller LV systolic and diastolic dimensions (LVDs and LVDd; Fig. 4, A and B, P Ͻ 0.05 for both) and LVMI (Fig. 4D, P Ͻ 0.05).
Compared with females with the same treatment, male HC or CIH had significantly greater LVDd, LVPWd, and LVMI, respectively (Fig. 4, B, C, and D, P Ͻ 0.01 respectively).
Figure 4G presents representative LV M-mode images from one offspring from each group.
The CIH males had the greatest value of LVEF and LV mass, while the CIH females had the smallest value of LV mass.
LV pressure-volume loop analysis.
Figure 5 summaries LV pressure-volume loop analysis performed at week 8.

For the males, compared with HC, CIH showed significant increases in LV systolic function, as suggested by "static" parameters such as LVEF and ϩdP/dt (Fig. 5, A and B, P Ͻ 0.05, respectively), as well as by pressure-volume parameters, including slope of the ESPVR (Fig. 5C) that represents the end-systolic elastance, and in preload recruitable stroke work (Fig. 5D).

Both occluded parameters are relatively independent of LV loading, including the aforementioned changes in BP, suggesting an elevated inotropic state in CIH males, likely resulting from LV hypertrophy.

Compared with HC males, CIH males also showed significant increases in the slope of the EDPVR (Fig. 5E), a relatively load-independent parameter, and in tau (Fig. 5F), which suggests a reduced LV compliance or elevated LV stiffness.

Moreover, compared with male HC, CIH males showed a significantly greater LVPd (Fig. 5G), and significantly lower LVVs (Fig. 5H), although no changes in LV end-diastolic volume (male HC vs. CIH: 260.5 Ϯ 31.2 vs. 256.2
Ratios of stroke volume or cardiac output to body weight were significantly greater in CIH males compared with male HC (male HC vs. CIH: 0.58 Ϯ 0.08 vs. 0.66 Ϯ 0.09 l/g and 165.1 Ϯ 18.2 vs. 185.6

Ϯ 21.3 l•min Ϫ1 •g Ϫ1 ; P Ͻ 0.05 for Fig. 4. Echocardiography at week 8. A-F: left ventricular (LV) dimension in systole and diastole (LVDs and LVDd), LV posterior wall thickness in diastole (LVPWd), and LV mass index (LVMI ϭ ratio of LV mass as tibial length), LV ejection fraction (LVEF), and LV fractional shortening (LVFS).
All the data were obtained in M-mode echocardiography at week 8. *P Ͻ 0.05 or **P Ͻ 0.01, compared with HC with same sex.
† †P Ͻ 0.01, compared with male with same treatment; n ϭ 16 for male HC, 18 for male CIH, 14 for female HC, and 12 for female CIH.
G: representative M-mode images from one 8-wk offspring each group; from left to right, male HC, male CIH, female HC, and female CIH.
Among the 4 animals, the CIH males had the highest values of LVEF and LV mass, and the CIH females had the lowest value of LV mass.

both), although the difference was insignificant in stroke volume (male HC vs. CIH: 162.9 Ϯ 19.3 vs. 171.1 Ϯ 21.6 l, P Ͼ 0.05) and cardiac output (male HC vs. CIH: 45.9 Ϯ 6.4 vs. 47.5 Ϯ 8.1 ml/min, P Ͼ 0.05).
Unlike the male offspring, there were no significant differences in these indexes between CIH females and their controls.
Compared with female CIH, male CIH had significantly greater ESPVR, EDPVR, tau, and LVPd (Fig. 5, C, E, and G, P Ͻ 0.05 or P Ͻ 0.01).
Compared with female HC, male HC had significantly greater LVVs (Fig. 5H, P Ͻ 0.01).
Figure 5I presents representative LV pressure-volume loops from one offspring in each group.
The CIH male had the greatest value of ESPVR and EDPVR.
Lipid peroxide and superoxide dismutase 1.
As previously described (8), oxidative stress may be involved in LV injury in rat and mouse models with postnatal CIH. Figure 6 shows indexes of oxidant stress.
Myocardial LPO (Fig. 6A) was significantly elevated in CIH males compared with male HC animals.
However, there were no significant differences between CIH and HC in the females.
There were no significant differences in the abdominal fat LPO between CIH and HC in either males or females (Fig. 6C).
Myocardial SOD1 activity (Fig. 6B) was elevated in both male and female CIH offspring compared with HC.
In the fat tissue, SOD1 activity (Fig. 6D) was greater in CIH males but not CIH females, compared with their respective HC.
Compared with female CIH, male CIH had significantly higher LPO in the heart (Fig. 6A, P Ͻ 0.01) and SOD-1 in the fat tissue (Fig. 6D, P Ͻ 0.05).
There were no significant differences between male and female HC in any indexes.
The main findings are that CIH exposure during gestation days 3-20 led to growth retardation in both male and female offspring compared with their respective HC.
However, there were effects found in male offspring that differed from those in females.
In male offspring, prenatal CIH caused signs of abdominal obesity, cardiovascular dysfunction, and LV oxidative stress; changes not observed in the females.
In the ensuing discussion, we consider these findings in the light of currently available literature.
Severe hypoxia and hypocapnic alkalosis during CIH exposure.
As shown in Table 1, CIH resulted in a range of severe arterial hypoxemia (arterial PO 2 in the 40s) with associated hypocapnic alkalosis.
Furthermore, recovery was not total during the normoxic phase (arterial PO 2 in the 70s), with milder hypocapnic alkalosis.
The hypocapnic alkalosis occurred only on the first day, suggesting development of chronic adaption on the days 3 and 15.
These changes are not unexpected, and the changes in arterial oxygenation were consistent with very severe OSA in humans.
The mechanism for hypocapnic acidosis in this model is likely the hypoxic ventilatory response.
We point out that, unlike the current model in human disease, and in experimental models of OSA, arterial PCO 2 increases because ventilation is decreased (hypopneas) or stops altogether (apneas).

In a previous study on large animals, using a model of OSA, Chen et al. (7) demonstrated that hypoxia was an important but not the sole factor responsible for the pressor response and consequent cardiac response to periodic apneas.
Hypercapnia per se was not primarily responsible for the cardiovascular response, although a contributory role was likely (7).
Thus we acknowledge that the cardiovascular response seen in our model may have been mitigated somewhat by hypocapnia.
However, the similarity of cardiovascular responses to those seen clinically suggests that the CIH model is a good one for understanding clinical disease.
Prenatal CIH induces growth retardation and visceral adiposity.
In this study, CIH exposure in pregnant rats was approximately equivalent to that of severe OSA in humans (8).
As shown in Figs. 1 and 2, both male and female CIH offspring had significantly lower body weight and tibial length, compared with HC.
This finding is consistent with previous rodent studies with in utero hypoxia consequent to cigarette smoke or other forms of hypoxia (22,23,51,54,65).
In humans, sustained maternal hypoxia can result from scenarios such as high altitude, maternal smoking, cardiopulmonary diseases, anemia, preeclampsia, and placental insufficiency.
Similar to our findings in rats, these conditions resulted in fetal growth restriction (FGR) (38,63).
It is estimated that FGR affects 7-10% of pregnancies or ~20.5 million infants each year (43,50).
FGR increases neonatal mortality and morbidity and the risk of diseases during adulthood as well (30).

For example, Goyal et al. (18,19) showed that low birth weight in mice may cause dysregulation of glucose metabolism as well as hypertension in later life with dysregulation of the renin-angiotensin system.
Our data demonstrate that even intermittent hypoxia for a limited portion of the 24 h day can result in FGR in rats.
Thus we speculate that OSA, which is accompanied by intermittent hypoxia in human pregnancy, could lead to FGR.
This possibility underscores the importance of screening for and treating pregnant women with OSA.
Numerous clinical studies suggest that obesity, especially visceral adiposity, contributes to adverse cardiovascular outcomes in many patients with OSA (48).

The process may be mediated through common pathophysiological mechanisms, such as sympathetic activation, systemic inflammation, oxidative stress, and metabolic dysregulation of lipids and glucose (48, 63a).
In the current study, the weight of abdominal fat pads was not different between prenatal CIH-exposed offspring and their HC in either sex.

However, abdominal fat pad weights normalized to either body weight or tibial length were greater in male CIH offspring compared with male HC, suggesting relative abdominal visceral fat accumulation in the males.
These effects were not seen in the female offspring.
In male rats, abdominal obesity increases the risk of adverse metabolic sequelae such as hyperglycemia, hyperinsulinemia, and hypoadiponectinemia (29).
Prenatal CIH may be a useful tool to study of potential mechanisms underlying abdominal visceral obesity with cardiovascular outcomes.
Prenatal CIH induces cardiovascular alterations and oxidative stress.
OSA in humans is associated with cardiovascular and metabolic disorders, including hypertension, cardiac injury, diabetes, and lipid disorders.
Indeed, postnatal CIH induces these cardiometabolic sequelae in rats and mice (8,9,11,13,15,20,25,42,44,45).

It is, therefore, not surprising that in utero insults, including chronic sustained hypoxia and exposure to certain pollutants, cause malfunction of the cardio- vascular and autonomic nervous system, including hypertension (17,59), elevated muscle sympathetic nerve activity (53), altered baroreflex and ventilatory responses to acute hypoxia (11,59), altered vascular reactions to vasoconstrictive and vasodilator agents (5,11,60,65), and in vitro LV dysfunction (31).
Some of these changes are sustained to adulthood (5,11,31,53,60,65).
Moreover, several studies showed that prenatal CIH, a more relevant model to human pregnancy with OSA, modified respiratory responses to hypoxia in neonatal (20) and adult offspring (21).

Our study further demonstrated postnatal hypertension in prenatal CIH-exposed male offspring at 8 wk of age, measured in the conscious or anesthetized state, although the underlying mechanisms, either by elevated peripheral resistance and/or elevated cardiac output, remain to be determined (37).
Unlike male offspring, CIH-exposed female offspring show only mildly elevated blood pressure while conscious and no change when measured under sedation.
The current study demonstrates that prenatal CIH leads to LV hypertrophy, elevated contractility and stiffness, and oxidative stress in near adult male but not female offspring.
Further studies, including use of older offspring, are needed for functional significance of the altered phenotype induced by prenatal CIH.

However, while increased LV stiffness can be a sign of LV diastolic dysfunction, myocardial hypertrophy and elevated contractility are not unusual in the early, compensatory, stage of hypertensive heart disease (61).
Myocardial hypertrophy can contribute to or confound other underlying pathologic mechanisms, such as myocardial apoptosis and oxidative stress (62), and advance to cardiac dysfunction.

Oxidative stress is one mechanism underlying cardiac injury in postnatal CIH exposure (8,9,64), which may be an underlying mechanism mediating cardiac changes due to fetal programming induced by prenatal hypoxia.

Recently, Zhu et al. (67) suggested that oxidative stress was responsible for prenatal hypoxia-induced upregulation of the vasoconstrictive response to angiotensin II; however, they did not study sex differences.
Sex differences in effects of prenatal CIH.

One important finding from this study is that there are sex differences in responses to prenatal CIH, with male offspring having more profound changes in BP, cardiac function, myocardial LPO content, and abdominal adiposity.
Offspring gender differences have been reported in outcomes of human pregnancy and delivery.
For example, the male sex is associated with significantly higher adverse outcomes of gestation and delivery and can be considered as an independent risk factor (1,14,16).
Surviving male infants show more profound neurocognitive injury in comparison to matched females with similar degrees of prematurity and intraventricular hemorrhage (49).
A study on twins suggests that perinatal hypoxia increased risks for autism spectrum disorder in males but not in females when evaluated at 4 -18 yr old (26).

In a rat model of intrauterine growth restriction due to prenatal hypoxia, Bourque et al. (5) reported that male, but not female, offspring at 21 mo of age exhibit altered mesenteric artery reactivity and endothelin-1 signaling.

Xiao et al. (65) demonstrated that prenatal hypoxia causes intrauterine growth restriction in both male and female offspring but increased angiotensin II-induced BP responses in male adult offspring, unlike decreased responses in female.

The sex-dependent effects were eliminated by ovariectomy but not by estrogen replacement, suggesting that ovarian dysfunction in females mediated the reduction in vascular contractility and BP in hypoxia.
Hauton et al. (31) studied isolated perfused adult rat hearts that were prenatally exposed to hypoxia.

Although both males and females showed signs of cardiac dysfunction, only females had compensatory responses, including a greater calcium turnover for improved contractility, and a greater coronary flow through increased expression of endothelial nitric oxide synthase protein that partially restored coronary perfusion.
Our current results confirm that male offspring exposed to prenatal CIH are more vulnerable to abdominal fat accumulation and cardiovascular dysfunction than females.
To date, the mechanisms are unknown but, as noted, could be related to differences in sex in utero continued postpartum.
This model thus would be useful to study the mechanisms underlying sex-dependent programming for offspring in human pregnancy with OSA.
Limitation of the study.

Human OSA features recurrent episodes of upper airway obstruction in sleep, which in turn, results in intermittent hypoxia, large swings in intrathoracic pressure, hypercapnia, acidosis, and disruption of sleep and arousal.

Clearly, unlike in human OSA, CIH that we chose for intervention of rat pregnancy was performed with fixed cyclic episodes of hypoxia-reoxygenation during daytime, normally sleeping hours for nocturnal animals, but not necessarily reflective of sleep-induced respiratory changes.
Moreover, CIH exposure leads to hypocapnia rather than hypercapnia and, likely, lacks large changes in intrathoracic pressure.
Like numerous studies using postnatal CIH, our prenatal CIH would be useful, since it mimics several sequelae as seen in human pregnancy with OSA.
However, further evaluations are necessary for better understanding of model-specific characteristics.
Future experiments using hypercapnic CIH (7), triggering CIH exposure by sleep (42), or using mother-child cohorts to correlate with research questions at epidemiological level (4) will be important.

Moreover, while the present study focused on accumulated effects of CIH, other studies have noted that the duration of the reoxygenation phase of the intermittent hypoxia cycle is important to elicit oxidative and/or hypertensive responses (35,55).
This phase-associated effect would justify further investigation using a modified model.

Recent animal and human studies suggest that chronic sustained hypoxia during pregnancy profoundly alters cardiovascular phenotypes (39,41), including growth restriction, left ventricular hypertrophy, and diastolic dysfunction (6,40).
Although prenatal CIH shares these features of chronic sustained hypoxia, it is possible that the effects of prenatal CIH differ from that of prenatal sustained hypoxia.

For example, unlike reduced body mass index and LV systolic contraction in prenatal sustained hypoxia (6,52), our results show that CIH in male offspring had opposite effects, as well as elevated myocardial oxidative stress.
These findings are consistent with previous studies in postnatal hypoxia, during which CIH and chronic sustained hypoxia may elicit different cardiovascular effects.
While the current study focused on left ventricular function, it is likely that prenatal CIH alters the phenotype of the pulmonary vasculature and right heart.
Indeed, adult rats who had transient prenatal hypoxia exposure during the first week of life demonstrated exaggerated pulmonary hypertension reexposure to hypoxia (28).
Consistently, previous studies demonstrated that postnatal CIH also leads to injury of pulmonary vasculature and the right heart in rats and mice (10,36).

In conclusion, while prenatal CIH induces growth retardation in both sexes of SD rats, male offspring are more vulnerable to prenatal CIH for cardiovascular abnormalities including hypertension, LV hypertrophy, and myocardial oxidative stress, which are sustained into adulthood.
The rat model of prenatal CIH appears to be a useful tool to study detrimental effects of maternal OSA in pregnancy to human offspring.
Fig. 1.
Body weight during postnatal weeks 4 -8.
Shown are means Ϯ SE.
CIH, prenatal chronic intermittent hypoxia; HC, handled normoxic controls; M, male; F, female.
*P Ͻ 0.05 or **P Ͻ 0.01, compared between CIH and HC at same time point with same sex.
†P Ͻ 0.05 or † †P Ͻ 0.01, compared between males and females at the same time points with the same treatment.

For clarity, significance symbols are omitted for comparisons among time points (P Ͻ 0.05 or P Ͻ 0.01 for all, compared with each earlier time point with the same sex and the same treatment); n ϭ 35, 34, 21, and 20 for male HC, female HC, male CIH, and female CIH, respectively.
Fig. 2. Tibial length (A), body weight (B), and weight of abdominal fat pads (fat weight; C and D) at week 8. *P Ͻ 0.05 or **P Ͻ 0.01, compared with HC with same sex.
† †P Ͻ 0.01, compared with male with the same treatment.
Fig.3.
Arterial pressure and heart weight at week 8. A: conscious systolic arterial blood pressure (SBP).
B-D: mean, systolic, and diastolic arterial blood pressure (MAP, SBP, and DBP) measured by intra-arterial catheter and under anesthesia.
*P Ͻ 0.05 or **P Ͻ 0.01, compared with HC with same sex.
†P Ͻ 0.05 or † †P Ͻ 0.01, compared with male with same treatment.
Sample size for A, E, and F: 35 for male HC, 21 for male CIH, 20 for female HC, and 34 for female CIH.
Sample size for B-D: 11 for male HC, 11 for male CIH, 12 for female HC, and 11 for female CIH.
Fig. 5. LV pressure-volume loop analysis at week 8. A: LV ejection fraction (LVEF).
B: rate of LV pressure rise (ϩdP/dt).
C: slope of end-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESPVR).
D: preload recruitable stroke work (PRSW).
E: slope of end-diastolic pressure-volume relationship (EDPVR).
F: isovolumic relaxation constant (tau).
G: LV end-diastolic pressure (LVPd).
H: LV end-systolic volume (LVVs).
*P Ͻ 0.05 or **P Ͻ 0.01, compared with HC with same sex.
†P Ͻ 0.05 or † †P Ͻ 0.01, compared with males with the same treatment; n ϭ 10 male HC, 11 for male CIH, 10 female HC, and 11 for female CIH.
I: representative diagrams of LV pressure-volume loop from one 8-wk offspring each group; from left to right, male HC, male CIH, female HC, and female CIH.
Note that the straight lines at top left represent ESPVR and the exponential lines on the bottom represent EDPVR.
Among the 4 animals, the male CIH had the highest values of ESPVR and EDPVR that indicate increased LV contractility and stiffness, respectively.
Fig. 6.
Oxidative markers in heart and abdominal fat tissues at week 8.
A and C: lipid peroxide (LPO).
B and D: superoxide dismutase-1 (SOD-1) or [Cu-Zn] superoxide dismutase.
Heart is left ventricular myocardium (n ϭ 8 each group); fat is abdominal white fat pads (n ϭ 10 ominal fat tissues).
*P Ͻ 0.05 or **P Ͻ 0.01, compared with HC with the same sex.
†P Ͻ 0.05 or † †P Ͻ 0.01, compared with males with the same treatment.
